awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Understanding the Late Paleozoic Icehouse from a Southern Hemisphere (Paranaì Basin, Brazil) paleo-perspective
awd_abstract_narration:
The late Paleozoic Ice Age is the longest-lived glacial interval of the past half billion years, sharing many parallels with the current icehouse in which humans evolved and live. During the Paleozoic icehouse (340 to 290 million years ago) atmospheric oxygen and carbon levels were anomalous, life moved onto land, the first wooded forests expanded across the Earth, and large-scale wildfires emerged.  Thus, it is important that we develop a more complete understanding of the late Paleozoic Earth and its dynamic glaciation history. The glacial-marine Parana Basin, Brazil provides an ideal opportunity for this work and the project will include training for U.S. and Brazilian students through seminars, field and lab work, and exchange visits.

This research will address three research objectives. First, an exportable, accurate and high-precision chronostratigraphic framework will be built by defining U-Pb zircon ages of unprecedented precision and accuracy for this region. This will permit testing of existing hypotheses of Gondwanan glaciation and will place constraints on the degree of synchronicity of the glaciations and establish the timing of terminal deglaciation in west-central Gondwana. Second, refined depositional and glaciation models will be developed through sedimentologic and detrital zircon provenance studies, integrated into the high-precision chronostratigraphic framework. This will place quantitative constraints on the timing, source, and geographic extent of glaciers feeding into the Parana Basin and permit reconstruction of changes in their glacial mass balance through time. Third, this research will develop U-Pb age-calibrated geochemical proxy records of continental climate variability that will test the hypothesis that major shifts in regional climate occurred in-step with periods of glacier advance/retreat and terminal deglaciation. This project will lead to a more complete understanding of icehouse to greenhouse transitions of the past.

por.por_cntn:
This work focused on strata of the Late Paleozoic Ice Age (LPIA) deposited in the Paran?, Chaco-Paran?, and Norte basins of Brazil and surrounding areas of South America and western Africa that fed ice into these linked basins. The LPIA represents the longest and only complete greenhouse-icehouse-greenhouse transitions (~370 to ~243 Ma) on a biologically complex Earth. Glaciers in these basins were sensitive to changing climatic conditions due to their mid to high latitude paleogeographic locations. Therefore, study of rocks deposited during this interval are critical in understanding deep time environmental change.

NW Namibia served as a source for glaciers that fed ice into the eastern Paran? Basin. The location of the ice spreading center may have been in Namibia or perhaps in eastern Africa. In contrast, in the SE portion of the Paran? Basin, paleovalleys thought to have formed as glacially carved fjords linked to ice draining out of southern Namibia, were instead formed as pull-apart basins in a reactivated strike-slip tectonic setting with sediment sourced locally. The valleys were not formed or influenced by glacial activity. However, basement rocks and sediment on the western side of the Rio Grande do Sul Shield farther to the west were striated and grooved by an ice sheet that extended out of Uruguay.

The orientations of subglacial landforms and glaciotectonic structures in Uruguay and southern Brazil indicate that the Norte, Chaco-Paran?, and southernmost Paran? basins were glaciated by the same ice sheet. This study also utilized U?Pb detrital zircon geochronology to assess the provenance of glacial and post-glacial sediments for these basins. In the Norte Basin, results show dominant age peaks at ~520?555 Ma, ~625 Ma, 750?780 Ma, and 900?1000 Ma in all samples indicating derivation from sources in the Cuchilla Dionisio Terrane and Punta del Este Terrane in SE Uruguay, and possibly the Namaqua Belt in southern Namibia. Another important source was likely Devonian sedimentary rocks of the Durazno Group in central/eastern Uruguay. Samples of the glaciogenic Itarar? Group from the southernmost Paran? Basin contain a different detrital zircon signature with peaks at ~580 Ma, ~780 Ma, ~2110 Ma, and ~2500 Ma that closely resemble underlying sedimentary and meta-sedimentary rocks of the Precambrian/Cambrian Camaqua Basin. Detrital zircon ages in the glacial and postglacial sediments indicate that local sources were dominant. In contrast, zircon ages from relatively ice-distal glaciomarine intervals in the Chaco- Paran? Basin reflect more distal sources to the east and southeast, which indicates a larger drainage catchment opened when glaciers retreated and/or the zone of maximum subglacial erosion shifted. Although most zircon ages in the Norte and Chaco-Paran? basins can be attributed to Uruguayan sources, results support the hypothesis that glaciers emanated from southern most Namibia and southeast Uruguay into these basins. The detrital zircon inventory in our study region is distinct from the eastern Paran? Basin, which suggest that at least two unique African source supplied ice to the South American basins.

It has long been hypothesized that ice crossed the Paran? Basin reaching its western margin. However, our work indicates that glaciers on the Asunci?n Arch in western Brazil and Paraguay fed ice eastward into the western portions of the basin. Farther south, early researchers suggested glaciers extended across the Chaco-Paran? Basin, crossed the Pampean Arch, and reached the western margin of Gondwana. We found no evidence for glaciation of the Pampean Arch. However, we found strong evidence for glaciation in uplifted areas of the tectonically active western convergent margin of Gondwana in western Argentina.   

Work by us and collaborators suggests that terminal LPIA deglaciation began in the highlands of western Argentina 319 Ma (Early Pennsylvanian) due to changing tectonic conditions and shifting orographic effects.  Work in conjunction with grant collaborators from the University of California-Davis and Berkeley Geochron place absolute age constraints on termination of glacial activity in the southern portion of the Paran? Basin by 296 Ma. Their work also identified that ice disappeared in the Karoo Basin in South Africa by 282 Ma. Thus, the timing of terminal glaciation in western Argentina, the Paran? Basin, and the Karoo Basin of South Africa indicates that a stepwise transition from icehouse to greenhouse conditions occurred across western Gondwana at the end of the LPIA. Terminal glaciation continued to shift across Gondwana and ended in eastern Australia during the late Permian. Such a diachronous change suggests local, regional, and global drivers all played a role in the termination of the LPIA.
